In this section, we outline the difficulties that arise when we try to optimize
Â EquationÂ 6 directly, without following the three stage procedure.
Let us consider question coding â€“ if we do not do question coding independently
of the answer, learning the parameters Î¸zsubscriptğœƒğ‘§\theta_{z} of the neural module network becomes
difficult, especially when N<<Mmuch-less-thanğ‘ğ‘€N<<M as the mapping pâ€‹(a|ğ³,ğ¢)ğ‘conditionalğ‘ğ³ğ¢p(a|\mathbf{z},\mathbf{i})
is implemented using neural modules pÎ¸zâ€‹(a|ğ¢)subscriptğ‘subscriptğœƒğ‘§conditionalğ‘ğ¢p_{\theta_{z}}(a|\mathbf{i}). This optimization
is discrete in the program choices, which hurts when qÏ•subscriptğ‘italic-Ï•q_{\phi} is
uncertain (or has not converged). Next, training the joint model without
first running module training is possible, but trickier, because
the gradient from an untrained neural module network would pass
into the qÏ•â€‹(ğ³|ğ±)subscriptğ‘italic-Ï•conditionalğ³ğ±q_{\phi}(\mathbf{z}|\mathbf{x}) inference network, adding noise to the updates.
Indeed, we find that inference often deteriorates when trained with
REINFORCE on a reward computed from an untrained network (TableÂ 1).

SHAPES results.
We focus on evaluating approaches by varying
the fraction of question-aligned programs
(which we denote %ğ±â†”ğ³\%\mathbf{x}\leftrightarrow\mathbf{z}) inÂ TableÂ 1.
To put the numbers in context, a baseline LSTM + image model, which
does not use module networks, gets an accuracy of 63.0%
on Test (seeÂ Andreas etÂ al. (2016); TableÂ 2). This indicates that SHAPES
has highly compositional questions which is challenging to model
via conventional methods for Visual Question AnsweringÂ (Agrawal etÂ al., 2015).
Overall, we make the following observations:

references:
CLEVR Results. Our results on the CLEVR datasetÂ (Johnson etÂ al., 2017) reflect similar trends as the results
on SHAPES (TableÂ 2). As explained inÂ SectionÂ 4, we work with 1000 supervised question
program examples from the CLEVR dataset (0.143% of all question program pairs).
With this, at the end of question coding,Â Prob-NMN gets to an accuracy of 93.15 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 8.61,
while the baseline NMN approach gets to an accuracy of 62.47 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 9.82.
These gains for theÂ Prob-NMN model are reflected
in module training, where theÂ Prob-NMN approach gets to an accuracy of 94.42 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 3.77,
while the baseline is at 79.26 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 4.03. At the end of joint training these improve
marginally to 95.52 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 4.15 and 79.38 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 4.21 respectively. Crucially, this is achieved
with a program generation accuracy of 93.87 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 8.73 by our approach compared to a baseline
accuracy of 63.08 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 9.91. Thus, the programs generated by theÂ Prob-NMN model are more
legible than those by the semi-supervised NMN approachÂ (Johnson etÂ al., 2017). Finally, the same
trends are reflected on the CLEVR test set as well, with Prob-NMN outperforming NMN.
We refer to the Appendix for more details of the training regime and architectural choices
